item.title: Bases for Topologies
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. To specify a topology on $X$, one needs to give a complete description of its open sets. In practice, however, specifying a certain subcollection $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ will suffice, In which case we say that the topology is generated by $\mc{B}$. Two questions arise: If $\mc{T}$ is a given topology on $X$, what subcollections $\mc{B}\subseteq\mc{T}$ generate $\mc{T}$? What kinds of collections $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ can specify some topology $\mc{T}$ on $X$?

item.title: Convergence
item.description: Motivation & Definition The idea of convergence of elements $x_\alpha$ in $X$ is to find a single element $x\in X$ that is ‘close’ to as many elements $x_\alpha$ as possible. This heuristic can be formalized in many ways; here, we focus on interpreting ‘closeness’ in the topological sense. Throughout, let $X$ be a topological space. item.title: Filter
item.description: Motivation & Definition Definition. Let $P$ be a poset. A filter on $P$ is a subset $\em\neq F\subseteq P$ such that (Upward-closure). If $p\in F$ and $q\geq p$, then $q\in F$. (Downward-directed). If $p_1,p_2\in F$, then there exists $q\in F$ with $q\leq p_1,p_2$.

item.title: Equivalence Relation
item.description: Motivation & Definition Oftentimes, we wish to regard two objects as ‘being the same’ (for instance, two sets are ‘the same’ if they have the same cardinality), despite them not being equal. The concept of an equivalence relation can be thought of as a generalization of equality. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. An equivalence relation on $X$ is a (binary) relation $E\subseteq X^2$ subject to the following conditions. (Reflexive). For all $x\in X$, we have $(x,x)\in E$.

item.title: Ideal
item.description: To study the quotient objects in a category, we must first understand the congruence relations in said category. For $\catring$, these are in correspondence with ideals. Definition. Let $R$ be a ring. A (left) ideal in $R$ is a subgroup $(\mf{a},+)\substructeq R$ such that $r\mf{a}\subseteq\mf{a}$ for all $r\in R$. Similarly for right ideals and two-sided ideals.

item.title: Module
item.description: Motivation & Definition Throughout, fix a ring $R$. Definition. A (left) $R$-module is an Abelian group $(M,+)$ equipped with a left $R$-action $R\to\End_\catabgrp(M)$. item.title: Ring
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a ring naturally arises when studying the endomorphism group of an abelian group $G$. Indeed, $\End G$ is itself abelian $-$ but more importantly, it has an extra operation of composition. These operations are compatible in the sense that: Definition. A ring is a monoid $(R,\cdot,1)$ equipped with the structure of an abelian group $(R,+,0)$ such that for all $r,s,t\in R$, we have $$\begin{equation} (r+s)\cdot t=r\cdot t+s\cdot t\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{and}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ t\cdot(r+s)=t\cdot r+t\cdot s.

item.title: Limits & Colimits
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a category $C$. Definition. Let $C,J$ be categories and fix a functor $F\in C^J$. A colimit of $F$ is a universal arrow $(r,u)$ from $F$ to the diagonal functor $\Delta:C\to C^J$. Similarly, a limit of $F$ is a universal arrow $(t,v)$ from $\Delta$ to $F$. item.title: The Yoneda Lemma
item.description: The Yoneda Embedding $\yo$ Statement & Proof Fix a locally-small category $C$. $\yo:C\to\catset$ Theorem (Yoneda). Let $C$ be a locally-small category. For every functor $F:C\to\catset$ and every object $c\in C$, we have a bijection $$\begin{equation} y\coloneqq y_{F,c}:\Hom(C(c,\slot),F)\to Fc\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{sending}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \big(\eta:C(c,\slot)\to F\big)\mapsto\eta_c1_c, \end{equation}$$ which is moreover natural in both $F$ and $c$. item.title: Universal Constructions
item.description: Motivation & Definition Universal Arrows Definition. Let $F:D\to C$ be a functor and fix $c\in C$. A universal arrow from $c$ to $F$ is an initial object in $(c\downto F)$. That is, it is a pair $(r,u)$, with $r\in D$ and $u:c\to Fr$, inducing for each $d\in D$ a bijection $$\begin{equation} \phi_d:D(r,d)\to C(c,Fd):f’\mapsto Ff’\circ u. \end{equation}$$ This can be visualized as in the following diagram. Remark. The bijection $\phi_d$ is natural in $d$, for if $g’:d\to d’$, then $$\begin{equation} F(g’\circ f’)\circ u=Fg’\circ(Ff’\circ u) \end{equation}$$ for every morphism $f’:r\to d$, making its naturality square commute.

item.title: Category
